docs.lead_paragraph: STEELY-EYED Mormon pioneers look down from yellowing portraits on the wall as Verde Hughes thumbs through a 40-year-old album of baby pictures, delivery room photographs from the days when the rock bungalow that is now the Desert Valley Museum was a one-room hospital. ''This was good enough for folks then, but I guess now we need something new,'' sighed Mrs. Hughes, the 80-year-old historian of this farming town-turned-retirement haven east of Las Vegas. ''But I won't go to any hospital. Last time I was in a hospital was when my babies were born. I've never been back and never will. Don't need no hospital.''

headline.main: On the Rainy Days in Mesquite, There's Always Politics

docs.abstract: Mesquite, Nev, is farming town that has turned into retirement haven, with population that went from 1,960 residents in 1990 to 13,500 today; it lures newcomers with its sunny weather, low taxes, new casinos, cheap utilities and little violent crime; retirees are seeking to influence local agenda, and this has precipitated political, cultural and social shift; city officials now wonder how much they must accommodate seniors they lured to town; photos (M)
